meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>help</kanji> with your <kanji>power</kanji>, you are providing <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>support</vocabulary>.

Note that this is a formal word that’s mostly used in professional situations. It implies that someone has done something substantial for you.

You are <kanji>alone</kanji> in what you are able to <kanji>create</kanji>. Nobody else can create like you. So what you create is your own <vocabulary>original creation</vocabulary>.

独創 refers to the act of <vocabulary>creating something original</vocabulary>, or the resulting creation itself. This word is quite formal, and generally used as 独創的 (original) or 独創性 (originality).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to submerge something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. So instead of describing something sinking on its own, you use 沈める when you sink an enemy ship or submerge yourself in a bathtub. 

You know this because you can't sink anything until you get that <reading>mail</reading> (める) saying, "Yes, proceed with sinking!" You've got to have that mail if you want to sink something, or else everyone will blame you for the missing ship — or for you disappearing under the water.

You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a <kanji>strap</kanji> (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a <vocabulary>cell phone strap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone strap</vocabulary>.
克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to conquer</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>philosophy</kanji> <kanji>scholar</kanji> (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a <vocabulary>philosopher</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>mourning</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> is your <vocabulary>mourning dress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mourning clothes</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>challenge</kanji> (挑戦) <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is going to challenge you. They are <vocabulary>a challenger</vocabulary>.

Remember how 揚げる means "to deep fry"? This is the prefix or suffix version of that word, making it <vocabulary>deep-fried</vocabulary>...

Note that 揚げ can sometimes be used as a standalone word, in which case it usually refers to deep-fried tofu.
Remember how 握る is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a <vocabulary>grip</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Shake</kanji> plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rock</vocabulary> slowly.

Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it <vocabulary>to be shaken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be jolted</vocabulary>. You know this because it's really <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for you to be shaken like this.
You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a <vocabulary>overnight stay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleepover</vocabulary>.

Remember how 滑る is "to slide," and 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, the "machine" you slide down is a <vocabulary>playground slide</vocabulary>, or just a <vocabulary>slide</vocabulary> for short.

Remember how 焦げる means "to get burned"? 焦がす is the transitive version, so this time someone is actively doing the burning, making it <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to scorch</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to char</vocabulary>.

焦がす means to burn the surface of something, usually blackening it to some degree. Unlike 焦げる, it can be for both intentional burning (a nice crème brûlée) and accidental burning (leaving bread in the toaster too long, scorching your sleeve on the stove).

You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word <vocabulary>to be diverted</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be distracted</vocabulary>.
The kanji is <kanji>distract</kanji> and the adjective version is <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misleading</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>net</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen door</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
A <kanji>wild</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> will make for some <vocabulary>stormy seas</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raging waves</vocabulary>. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a sack for your hands... better put, these are <vocabulary>gloves</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>dragon</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a <vocabulary>tornado</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>fear</kanji> <kanji>dragon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dinosaur</vocabulary>. Dinosaurs are much, much scarier than dragons, and that's why dinosaurs are called fear dragons in Japanese.

The <kanji>edge</kanji> of <kanji>wake up</kanji> is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an <vocabulary>omen</vocabulary>... an omen that will show the truth.
If something has a <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>edge</kanji>, it's probably <vocabulary>unrelated</vocabulary> to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.

Let's take the <kanji>edge</kanji> and <kanji>discuss</kanji> it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a <vocabulary>marriage proposal</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left wing</vocabulary>, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right wing</vocabulary>. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Having <kanji>good luck</kanji> is a <vocabulary>good omen</vocabulary> to have. Good luck means more good luck, right?

Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good luck</kanji> is <vocabulary>ominous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sinister</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>bad luck</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>ill omen</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>conceal</kanji>ed <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who can conceal themselves. Who's better at that than anyone? A <vocabulary>ninja</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>blade</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is an <vocabulary>edged tool</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cutlery</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>blade</kanji>'s <kanji>ahead</kanji> is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the <vocabulary>edge of the blade</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>blade edge</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>peach</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is a <vocabulary>peach color</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pink</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word mean exactly the same thing. That makes this a <vocabulary>mystery</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>riddle</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mystery</kanji>, doubled? Hm, this is truly a <vocabulary>riddle</vocabulary>. You could even call it a <vocabulary>puzzle</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>enigma</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scold</kanji> and the verb vocab version also means <vocabulary>to scold</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Recreation</kanji> and <kanji>comfort</kanji> are things you do for <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amusement</vocabulary>. So nice!
How much can you hold in this <kanji>ladle</kanji>? Why, exactly <vocabulary>eighteen liters</vocabulary> of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

朱 refers to <vocabulary>vermilion</vocabulary>, a bright red color with a slight orange tint, and can also be translated as <vocabulary>scarlet red</vocabulary>. It's common in Japanese culture — you'll often see it on shrine gates and lacquerware, for example.
A <kanji>vermilion</kanji> colored <kanji>seal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>red seal</vocabulary>. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>hill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sand dune</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this means <vocabulary>pear</vocabulary> too.

Note that 梨 usually refers specifically to the spherical <vocabulary>Asian pear</vocabulary>. When you want to refer to the teardrop-shaped European variety of pear, use the word 洋梨 (ようなし).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shout</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>. Can also be <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Extinction</kanji> caused by a <kanji>shout</kanji>. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> over them. You are making an <vocabulary>exclamation</vocabulary>, gosh darn it.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fishing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fish</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
<kanji>Gold</kanji> <kanji>hair</kanji> is <vocabulary>blonde</vocabulary> hair. Makes sense!
Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>fur</kanji> is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your <vocabulary>head hair</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is how you model your hair. It's your <vocabulary>hairstyle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hairdo</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cannon</kanji> is... wait for it... just a <vocabulary>cannon</vocabulary>. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.

An excess of <kanji>feeling</kanji> produces <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s. These are <vocabulary>tears of emotion</vocabulary>, but not the bad kind. You're just <vocabulary>being moved to tears</vocabulary>.

感涙 is an advanced word mainly used in writing. It refers to the kind of tears you might shed when you're profoundly touched with positive emotion, like when you're truly grateful for something or moved by a powerful speech.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>can</kanji> <kanji>coffee</kanji> (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's <vocabulary>canned coffee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>can coffee</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>noble girl</vocabulary> as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
The <kanji>princess</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the <vocabulary>princess</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Grains</kanji> are made of single <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary>s. You can also use this to refer to a <vocabulary>bead</vocabulary> or use it as a <vocabulary>counter for grains</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>grain's</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is even smaller than a grain. It's a <vocabulary>particle</vocabulary>, sometimes even an <vocabulary>atomic particle</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>thunder</kanji> <kanji>rain</kanji> is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think <vocabulary>thunderstorm</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Fish</kanji> <kanji>thunder</kanji> is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a <vocabulary>torpedo</vocabulary>. Load the fish thunder!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a <vocabulary>pagoda</vocabulary>. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.

The <kanji>pipe</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> <kanji>tower</kanji> is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the <vocabulary>control tower</vocabulary>.
バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the <vocabulary>Tower of Babel</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>Eiffel</kanji> (エッフェル) <kanji>tower</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Eiffel Tower</vocabulary>.
逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your <kanji>see</kanji>ing, then you are going <vocabulary>to overlook</vocabulary> it.
The thing you want to <kanji>take</kanji> has <kanji>escape</kanji>d. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is <vocabulary>to fail to catch</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a <vocabulary>bed</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>crib</vocabulary>. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.

You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your <kanji>hand</kanji> is <kanji>solid</kanji> and tough, it's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steady</vocabulary>. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.

荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." 荒らす is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying <vocabulary>to lay waste</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to mess up</vocabulary> everything around you.

荒らす is all about creating a mess. It can be physical destruction, like a wild pig tearing up a garden or a robber ransacking and messing up a house. Or it can refer to disrupting a peaceful situation, such as trolling an online forum or chat.
荒い is <kanji>rough</kanji>. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.

This <kanji>measurement</kanji> also refers to a specific measurement, a "<vocabulary>sun</vocabulary>", which is about <vocabulary>3.03 centimeters</vocabulary>. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.

One of the easiest <kanji>method</kanji>s of <kanji>measurement</kanji> is to just check the <vocabulary>size</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dimension</vocabulary>s, and there you go, you've got the <vocabulary>measurement</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Before</kanji> you take the last <kanji>measurement</kanji>, you know you're <vocabulary>on the brink</vocabulary> of something.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

縁 often describes the physical outlines of something, such as メガネの縁 (frames of glasses) or 池の縁 (the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of a pond).
<kanji>Thunder</kanji> that <kanji>fall</kanji>s from the sky is a <vocabulary>thunderbolt</vocabulary>.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is just <vocabulary>a part </vocabulary>of the bird or plane it's attached to. But that one wing plays <vocabulary>a role</vocabulary> that's very important!

This word usually comes up in the phrase 〜の一翼を担う (to play a part in…).
<kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>both wings</vocabulary>! There are two and you have them all!

<kanji>Line up</kanji> <kanji>house counters</kanji> and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same <vocabulary>across the board</vocabulary>. It also turns them into a <vocabulary>row of houses</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Push open</kanji> the door to the conversation that is going to <kanji>be imminent</kanji> by saying the proper <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>salutation</vocabulary>. This word might also refer to a short <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> you give at an event or ceremony.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>split</kanji>, so this verb has to do with something splitting. 

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be torn</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to burst apart</vocabulary>.

What can you see in the <kanji>north</kanji> that looks like a <kanji>ladle</kanji> and is made up of <kanji>seven</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji>s? That's the group of stars we call <vocabulary>the Big Dipper</vocabulary> or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps <vocabulary>the Plough</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>ladle</kanji> <kanji>can</kanji> is a <vocabulary>eighteen-liter container</vocabulary>, which is also a <vocabulary>five-gallon container</vocabulary>. That must be one big ladle!

If you live in Japan you've probably seen these. They're rectangular shaped containers made of metal that are used mostly for industrial purposes, for storing liquids like paint, fuel and chemicals. The 斗 actually refers to an old Japanese measurement, which is roughly equivalent to eighteen liters.
<kanji>Earth</kanji> and <kanji>sand</kanji> is <vocabulary>earth and sand</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sediment</vocabulary>.
For the <kanji>sake</kanji> of <kanji>exchange</kanji>! What sounds so glorious is really just <vocabulary>currency exchange</vocabulary>.

You're free to <kanji>choose</kanji> and <kanji>select</kanji> any of these <kanji>limb</kanji>s, leaving you many <vocabulary>choices</vocabulary>. With all these <vocabulary>options</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>alternatives</vocabulary>, which one will you go for?
